newsitem.title: USA: US Aug 1 pork belly stocks seen at nine-year low.
newsitem.headline: US Aug 1 pork belly stocks seen at nine-year low.

text.p: Frozen pork belly stocks in U.S. warehouses as of August 1 likely remain at a nine-year low, analysts said.

The U.S. Agriculture Department will release its monthly Cold Storage Report at 1400 CDT Friday and analysts forecast the data will show August 1 stocks between 35.1 million and 38.7 million lbs versus July 1 stocks of 56.767 million and August 1, 1995, stocks of 47.055 million.
Continued demand from the fast food sector through the month of July kept the flow of frozen bellies strong and stocks at low levels, analysts said.

"The drawdown during the month as a percentage to the stocks that we had, was a little larger than average and as a result the 38.5-million-lb figure that we have on hand as of August first is the lowest number we've had for that date since 1987," said Chuck Levitt, senior livestock analyst for Alaron Trading Corp.
Levitt noted that the larger percent of usage came despite wholesale bacon prices that are double the price of last year.
Expectations following the June 1 USDA Hogs and Pigs Report pointed to increased hog numbers. Users gambled that fresh production would jump late this summer and used frozen stocks to fill needs.
However, hog slaughter has not risen to expectations and usage of frozen product continues large.
